												I have always enjoyed the first two Final Fantasy games, but their stories were sparse, relying more on conversations with random town folk to help fill in the blanks than to tell a proper tale. While Final Fantasy III still shows its age and might not have the sophistication found in later RPGs, it is still a worthy look back at a game that helped to continue to redefine the genre. This version of the game on PC is based on the graphically updated version that made its way onto the Nintendo DS back in 2006. The visuals got an 3D overhaul, with a widened aspect ratio and some new features as well. If you are familiar with the DS or iPhone/iPad versions of the game this PC release will feel very familiar, but it still plays out nicely on a bigger screen.Themes that persist and remain familiar in future Final Fantasy games such as the Warriors of Light and job class systems help populate this story. The job system is bare bones compared to what we are used to now in the series (and other games that use similar systems), and the game uses it more as a second experience system. On the one hand the characters have conventional experience systems that level up their physical attributes, and then there's the job levels which represent their skills. Managing both is easy, and the system does encourage players to jump their characters through multiple jobs, though there is some grinding involved as there is a warmup process where a character needs to fight a certain number of battles with a role before they're comfortable with it and can use its skills properly. You don't want to be fighting tough enemies in such a state, so you'll generally grind through easy battles each and every time you change classes.This is a classic Final Fantasy title, which of course has both good and bad connotations. It means lots of menus and level grinding and of course chocobos and Cid and things. It is a welcome rush of nostalgia to come back to a game like this, which has aged well despite being nearly two and a half decades old. I'd be lying if I said that the graphical overhaul didn't make the game far more palatable (or the fact that the original game was never released in English), but the core mechanics should also appeal to old school JRPG fans. The game gets off to something of a slow start, with a lot of story and limited exploration during the first dozen hours or so, but once it opens up it is every bit the exploration-filled adventure Final Fantasy is known for, filled with little secrets to find and fun and diverse characters.Having just played Bravely Default a few months ago and seeing familiar themes such as the four different adventurers brought together by circumstance and the presence of crystals as a focal point to the story, I could not help but be amused with how timeless the narrative themes are. That being said, Bravely Default showed just how much further game storytelling has gone in making something rich out of the basic thematic construct. That is not to say that Final Fantasy III has a poor story, but compared to the more modern Japanese role-playing game, it is fascinating to see how far the medium has come.If you have already played the DS or iOS version of this game, there may not be enough of a reason to purchase it on Steam now. However, if you missed that opportunity before and want to experience an important part of Final Fantasy's early evolution, this is an excellent way to do so. The character depth and story detail might feel somewhat lacking compared to newer JRPG titles, but there is an expansive world here that begs for exploration as you grow your characters for future challenges. The overall package is an easy one to recommend.Recommended

												Just to start off, if you're looking at this game as a potential gateway to getting into traditional JRPG's, don't bother.  It will only serve to put you off the genre all together.  There are just too many things, like lack of save points and some cheap bosses, for someone that may want to play a more old-school game and is looking at FFIII, the earliest available FF game on Steam, as the game to start out with.That said, if you've played a lot of old RPG's growing up, you may find something more to your liking here.  The story and characters are simple.  There's no voice acting, no FMV cutscenes, no minimap or compass to point you in the right direction.  I found all of the above a benefit to the game.  The story parts would be slowed down by voice acting and the generic story would be exposed further if you had to listen to it and instead of just reading text.  While the game is fairly linear, it does a great job at points of making you wonder where to go and there's a real sense of exploration.  There's like five or more villages you don't ever have to go to for any reason that are just there, and despite them being pretty small, it's a cool little thing that you'd never see in a more modern game.The big thing with this game is that in was the introduction of the job-swapping system found in the earlier FF's.  There are twenty plus jobs and they're handed out at set points in the story.  The big problem is the last set of jobs are unlocked extremely late in the game and this makes using them to their fullest a pain.  You can switch jobs on the fly but there's a small penalty to stats for x amount of fights.  It's not a big deal and will only hamper you for a handful of random battles.The big downside to the game is complete lack of effort when redesigning the boss encounters and the final dungeon in its entirety.  Every boss fight boils down to the same thing.  A single enemy will have a strong physical attack that hits one character and strong magic attacks that hits everyone.  Bosses will also always use these attacks back to back without interruption.  This means any character, even with full HP, is liable to get KO'd if they get RNG unlucky when it comes to boss turns versus your characters' turns.  It's such a cheap, low-effort way to add difficulty when designing bosses.  Every turn of every boss fight eventually winds up with you casting a group heal spell on an already fully healed group just to deal with the oncoming attacks. The last dungeon and it's surroundings is one of the worst in RPG's and I'm sure you can find detailed reasons why elsewhere.There's a lot of talk about grinding being necessary in this game and I find that completely overblown.  I never stopped my progress for the explicit grinding of levels/ job levels and beat the game with levels in the very low 50's.  Grinding some levels would have helped for the last boss to serve as an HP buffer but it's not necessary.  As long as you don't continuously change your jobs, you should be able to handle anything the game can throw at you as long you fight every random encounter you come across.  The secret boss though would require a ton, and I mean a ton, of grinding and I didn't bother with it.As for the port, it's a super low effort one of the mobile version, not the DS version.  This means stuff like the UI is ugly and created to be touch based, but lacking in touch suport or mouse control in menus in this version and is just poor all around.  Even things like loading your game while in-game is obtuse.  There are only three save slots for who knows what reason.  I also ran into a problem where all dialogue box text had some type of artifacting or something that I couldn't find a work around for.  All that said, it's still supposedly better the FFIV PC port, which doesn't even have the memorize battle cursor function because it wasn't included in the mobile version and has 15 FPS in battles.  I used the memorize function in FFIII so I'll be missing it when I eventually get around to playing FFIV.  Square just doesn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥with any of their PC ports so none of this should be a surprise.  Okay, since this was really long, here's a short answer as to whether you should buy and play this game.  Don't if you have no experience with older RPG's.  If you do and are fine with not having things like save points and easily obtainable reviving items, cheap bosses and a terrible final dungeon, you'd probably get some enjoyment out of FFIII.  It's an enjoyable, but clearly flawed game.

												This game is an excellent old school Rpg, emphasis on the old school. Remember this game was orginally released April 1990 ( in Japan only), to put that in perspective it, Final Fantasy 1 came out for the NES in America that year! This version is a direct port of the DS version, which updated the graphics to a 3D engine.There is very little hand holding, often you will find yourself on the world map trying to remember a single line of dialogue from an NPC that will direct you. While the flow of the game is pretty good, there is a few times that you will need to grind out levels (and Job levels). Again, part of the old school feeling of this game.The Job system works for the most part and is designed to suit individual playstyles. Unfortunately there is many bosses that die easier to certain group make-ups. This can be a frustrating thing. Also a few of the jobs are direct upgrades from other jobs (white mage / devout or Monk / Black belt) rendering the previous job basically  obsolete.Graphics    Well not the best looking game the graphics do a servicable job. This will not put your system to the test that is for sure!Sound     The music and sound effects are pretty good and definitely have that "final fantasy" feel. Story      As mentioned above the flow of the game is ok, but you do find yourself at certain points wondering where to go next (at least I did, anyway). Revisiting a couple of towns and talking to everyone may refresh the memory.Gameplay      Old school! Grinding levels although arguably not required is recommended. The Job levels have a different leveling system, as in they don't level up using Experience points. There is a hidden job point system that sets your levels. To accumulate these job points you perform actions in battle (attack, guard, item, magic etc.)  When JP is accumulated to 99, Job level goes up by 1. Each action (except: Front, Back, Escape, and Flee) will contribute a fixed amount of job points to the character.       My only real complaint is when entering a battle the camera system often scrolls through the enemies. Really it comes down to like 3 seconds but when you're grinding levels it makes each battle longer than maybe it should be, this adds up over time. Again, just a very small gripe.      There is very large portion of the game at the end where you are unable to save. Although I was lucky and got through it all unscathed, I can imagine the frustration of dieing and losing everything after sinking a couple of hours into the dungeon. Save and save often! Even if you don't think you need to!Overall I recommend this game especially if you're into Jrpg, and specifically ones from the past! :)8/10

Although, FFIV will always be my favorite of the older series and XIII for the later series.  Pure, unspoiled Final Fantasy at its best. I first played this game back in 2006 when it was introduced stateside to the Nintendo DS and I loved every freaking minute of it. Final Fantasy III is a sweet, charming, and satisfying Final Fantasy experience. The style of the music, the artwork, and the feel of the game has yet to be replicated.Luneth, Arc, Inguis, and Refia are four adventurers who become the Warriors of Light. Their roles in the party are based on which jobs you assign to them that unlock as you progress through the story. The story is simple but engaging enough to want to see through to the end.This game is HARD, especially when you're used to the more modern FF titles. I can't sugarcoat the difficulty at all. You will rarely get a phoenix down, so trips back to town to revive fallen party members may happen frequently. If you are looking for a challenge, you will certainly find it here. It's kinda sad that it took over a decade for this gem to see a US release, but it has already taken place as one of my favorite games of all time and one of my favorite FF titles. Completing this game is one of the most rewarding experiences ever. I recommend getting both FF3 and FF4 on Steam as both are challenging in their own ways but offer different experiences.

												I've been a Final Fantasy buff for nearly 2 decades and 3 was one of those elusive games I never got to play due to the original never making its way to the West.  Thankfully this has been changed and the game got a nice faithful remake.  All I can say is WOW - I do not know how this game avoided a Western release the first time around, it was fantastic. All the making of a traditional FF world (4 Crystals, Warriors of Light, etc. etc.) - and with enough flair and uniqueness to quite distinguish it from basically every other FF game even into modern iterations (I really liked the idea of '2 worlds' one being a floating continent).The Job system is awesome and offers a huge variety of choices but does promote some serious grinding if you're into switching around.  If you don't like to grind then chances are you will finish the game with the default classes (Warrior et al.)Probably the biggest downside to the game is that it features the archaic 'only 3 spells per level' mechanism that existed in FF1 and 2 - this is further aggitated by the fact that the game is no longer limited to simply White and Black Magic - you also have to find room to put your Summons in one of those 3 precious slots per level.  However I can understand that the game is technically just a faithful remake, and the system is what it was when 3 released in Japan.Storywise this really feels like an early FF - and by that I mean the story is trivial at best (same as I and II).  You could text mash the whole game and you'd likely find you like it just the same as long as you like FF/JRPGs.  That being said - it's not an issue of the story being "bad" so much as the story just didn't latch for me.Graphically it isn't too bad - it stands somewhere around where 7 does graphically.  7 makes use of parallax backgrounds and imaging layers to give the impression of better 'graphics' for their environments - but when you look at the character models you can see the difference - especially in meshing.   FF7 has better environments, but FF3's character models' meshes and overall 3D details are better - textures are bit poop, but still better than FF7s in most cases.  All in all it was a positive experience and one day I'll probably play again just for the fun of it.

												Final Fantasy III is a nice JRPG but definitely shows its age. This PC port is based on the Nintendo DS-Version from 2006 which itself is a port of the original NES game from 1990. The graphics are done in a reduced chibi-style that may not be everybody's cup of tea, but all models are surprisingly faithful to the original. Pro: - The barebone story is somewhat extended compared to the original- The job system is pretty flexible and allows for some experimentation.- Even without a real help box like in the FF6 remake you always know where to go next- ~20+h of playtime without doing the superbossCon:- Formulaic "Go rescue the world" story- Turn based combat with a large random element to the speed stat. This can lead to some bad luck in boss combats which otherwise would be pretty easy - Weird difficulty progression: Some bosses in the mid game are much more difficult than the enemies in the surrounding area would suggest- No save points in dungeons. The final dungeon takes over an hour to complete. If you die on the final boss you can repeat everything- Itemization of some classes is strange. My black and white mage wore their starting head gear up to the last part of the final dungeon- Changing job classes takes a looooot of grinding and some jobs become available really late. I ended up with just changing the job of 1 character to an advanced job class and still could finish the game without much problem.Despite some of the shortcomings, FF III is enjoyable enough for an in its core 26 year old game. If you want to experience the evolution of the Final Fantasy games this is a good starting point that already has some of the elements and comfort found in later games, but is still charmingly unpolished.

												After playing the Famicom version of this game, I was hesitant to give this remake a try.  I have to say I was pleasantly surprised at how much of an improvement this game made over the original.  Rather than make an essay about the changes, I'll go point-by-point.+ Better graphics, obviously.  Granted, the Famicom version looked marvelous in the 8-bit era, but since this is a PC-optimized port of the DS game, I'm glad to see some 3D graphics in there.+ Better story.  The plot was a lot looser in the original, and the characters had no backstory at all.  By assigning default names to each character and expanding on their origins, the plot feels more cohesive and I connect with the characters better.+ Better use of the job system.  It's still not as crisp as Final Fantasy V, but the major gripe I had playing the Famicom version is that many job types became obsolete very quickly.  Some were never useful from the start, and the Scholar job was only necessary for one boss fight.  This remake changed all of that.  More jobs are useful for longer periods of time, and even in the late-game stages you can downgrade to a lesser job and still function well.+ Better difficulty curve.  The original game was HARD.  Frankly, without a strategy guide, beating that game would have been near impossible.  But the remake softens the blow a lot and makes the game much more enjoyable.  You never feel like you're bringing the game to a screeching halt so that you can grind job levels or character levels.  It flows much more smoothly.Overall, this game was in dire need of a remake, and this one does the job quite well.  If you've never played Final Fantasy III, or if the Famicom version left a bad taste in your mouth, then I strongly recommend picking this up.  You'll be glad you did.

												While it is a port of the DS remake, it has enough of the simplicity and that grindy flavor to hit the spot for that early Final Fantasy JRPG nostalgia (note: I've experienced no issues with the port).Much of this is owed to the fact that this game is almost a verbatim remake, which reflects the restrictions of the ancient technology of 1990, when the game was first released. The redsign of the game was primarily only a visual & audio makeover (updated music, '3D' environments & sprites, etc). The gameplay and construction are almost identical to the original.This means that there really isn't much at all to the story, and the characters are pretty much completely flat. So if you're expecting the rich development you'd find in the story and characters of the later installments in the series (pretty much any of them after this one), look elsewhere. Further, the maps used in the original games have been retained here - and that includes the limitations in design, as  So, similar to the limited story, dialogue, and characters, you'll find that they're disappointingly simple. While all the above might seem like a pile of complaints, it's actually not. What has been redone, has been redone well. The visuals are limited to that of a DS, however im finding that the music is really enjoyable. All in all, it's been a fun experience - just don't expect this to compare to the modern (high-budget) maserpieces that the Series produces. Bottom line: if you're looking for a nostalgic feel with a bit of modern flavor, this just might hit the spot.

												The best way to play Final Fantasy III? The Nintendo DS remake.The next-best way to play Final Fantasy III? The PC port of the Android port of the DS remake--in other words: this.There are three facts you need to be aware of:1. Final Fantasy III, like most of the old Square and Enix games pre-dating their unfortunate merger, is an absolute classic.2. This game is a remake of Final Fantasy III. A true remake, not a port/update/remaster/whatever new marketing term people are using to pretend lazy ports are better than they are.3. But it's also a port, ya' know? And not a very good one. I'm not sure, but it may in fact simply be running the Android version remulated. Want the game to display 16:9 at 1080p? Sure, you can select that in the options menu--you can select lots of stuff--but no matter what you select, you get a letterboxed game screen. Want a smooth, 60fps framerate? Haha, no. Willing to settle for simply a smooth framerate? Sorry, but still no. The game is locked at 30fps and will frequently dip below that in combat. We're talking 24-28fps stuttering depending on how fancy the combat animation is.Final Fantasy III is a classic game, and that counts for a hell of a lot. And if you want to play the game on a big (at least relatively speaking) screen, the only "legitimate" (read: legal) way to do so is to buy this particular port. Otherwise the best option is the NDS original (the original remake, not the original NES game).

												This sure is Final Fantasy 3, firstly i want to talk about the port, this is a bare bones cheap and nasty port from the mobile version straight to the PC, no bells, no whistles, and considering that the android and iOS version is itself a port from the DS remake what we have here is some butt ugly textures and models being displayed at a high resolution that does them no courtesy, the sound is straight from the DS is is everything else, the game doesnt even fit to the proper aspect ratio, be prepared for 2 black bars to run vertically down the sides of your screen, there are barely any options to toggle this game has trading cards and controller support and that is literally about it, not enough to justify the price for anyone familiar with FF3The first three Final Fantasy games are very easy to group together, they are easilly the worst the franchise (with the exception of 13 and its iterations) but they are still important games that made mistakes that would only surface themselves through time. 3 has a class system in place that anyone familiar with 5 or 14 should feel comfortable with, you can select Jobs and level them individually as well as level your own characters base stats. 5 handles this better but this is the first FF game to bring in the system, personally id argue 3's biggest flaws are the same as FF1 and FF2's flaws but on a larger scale, Heavy grinding, vague story and a large overworld easy to get lost in, this to some people sounds like hell while to others it probably sounds great, this is an NES era RPG and this port doesnt do much to change that for better or for worse. its still a cracking game albeit one i feel that has aged the least well, with a very large difficulty curve (that frog tower...oh my god) that is showing its age. If your already familiar with FF3 and merely looking to see what this PC port brings to the table, i cant recommend that the price is worth your time, equally if your looking for a decent JRPG on the PC, the poor port quality and how harsh and aged this game really is means that i cant recommend this over say child of light or Recettear.However if you are intruiged to see what FF3 brings to the table on its own, and dont have access to the mobile ports (which could likely be found cheaper for the exact same content) and the sounds of a tough as nails old school JRPG sound good to you, then id recommend jumping in, maybe during a sale, theres just no reason this game should cost this much, 50% off though and id say go for it,

												Turn-based RPG, before the days of the active time battle, there were the originals, this is a remake of Final Fantasy III originally released exclusively in Japan for the "Family Computer" ... That's how old the mechanics/storyline are. HOWEVER, there have been quite a few tweaks made to bring it up to date with what you would expect of a good RPG ... In the 90's. As far as storyline goes, it's pretty bland and generic. Collect the crystals, beat the bad guys, save the world. It does have some hidden humorous elements in it, but they're few and far between. This game is badly dated, but it's still a solid essential for a Final Fantasy fan, and it is enjoyable up to about level 40, when the grind from 40-60 begins, it will take you about three hours on a good day, and you pretty much need to be 60 to beat the game. DO NOT go into this game thinking you will 100% every aspect of it, and if you do, for the sake of sanity, make sure you kill every sea creature while you still have your sea boat, or you'll be SOL for getting that beastiary achievement. You will not want to replay this game. Sad but true, it's just not that immersing compared to later Final Fantasy games.There are no voiceovers as seen in FFIV, there are summons, which are cool.TL;DRGrindfest, random-battle hell, old-school level up, good world maps, sometimes even surprising, bosses are not overly frustrating (There is no boss in this game that will one-shot your entire party* like later Final Fantasy games), bland storyline, decent graphics, decent amount of secrets. Overall a B- as far as RPGs are considered. There just isn't much to this game to compare with newer titles.*There is a boss that will one shot your party, but it is meant to happen, there is no way out of it, don't freak when it does happen.

												I wish there was another option besides "recommended" and "not recommended," because I'd give this game a "meh" if I could. I don't hate it, I just think it's the weakest of the first five Final Fantasy games--and the 3D remake doesn't really improve anything.Aesthetically, I liked the chibi/Mii/MySims-looking character models more than I thought I would. Your main characters are all adorable, and the costumes for all the different classes are fairly detailed and interesting (though they look better in the menu thumbnails). But the character models are also really twitchy during battle sequences.In general, I'm a big fan of the art style used for the Game Boy Advance remakes of these games. The smaller, more realistic sprites did a good job of capturing the dark, intricate, fantastical feel of the classical Final Fantasy universes. Look at the concept art from FFI-V. It's all weird, exotic, and unearthly, and I think the GBA remakes did a much better job capturing that feel with their overall designs. This game, however, goes for a more generic, cartoony atmosphere as part of an appeal to younger and more casual gamers. The backgrounds to the battle sequences are the only truly appealing visual element in the game. Environments look empty and bland, both in the overworld and in towns and dungeons. Enemy models lack detail and also come across as bland. One of the advantages of the hand-drawn sprites from the GBA games is that they portray each enemy in a carefully designed, static pose, so each enemy gets to look pretty cool. In a 3D game, you see the whole enemy, and the enemy moves around even when it isn't attacking, so most enemy models come across as lackluster or unimpressive.The transition to 3D also changes the way your character moves in the game. Instead of moving tile-by-tile, you have free range of movement--which means your character will get stuck on corners a lot. Furthermore, the near walls in every dungeon consist entirely of empty shadows, and it be difficult to see certain doors and entrances as a result (although hidden passages are usually grossly obvious). I imagine I would enjoy this game more if I played it on the DS. The default keyboard controls are about as unintuitive as possible, and you can only change the controls on the start-up menu before you actually launch the game. A GBA remake would have been even better, I think, but I still think I would consider it my least favorite original Final Fantasy game.For one thing, while the game has a fine story, the pacing and exposition are weird. You often have to extrapolate beyond what characters say if you want to have any clue what's actually going on. Usually, a FF game's story is easy to follow despite its many twists and turns, but this game has you holding on for dear life in terms of comprehension. One problem is that the game is a little too open-ended at points. You can often start down several storylines by visiting different towns, but you may have to wait for a few dungeons and crucial plot developments before these storylines ever feature into the central plot. The game allows for a lot of exploration, which is fun in its own right, but there aren't always worthwhile rewards to finding new areas before you're "supposed" to.Also, the game has a frustrating tendency to almost require you to switch jobs in certain ways at certain places. For instance, the game features multiple (multiple!) dungeons that require you to traverse them under the effects of the spell Mini--which essentially makes all your physical fighters useless. Other sections of the game clearly push you toward   classes like the dragoon or the dark knight by giving you loads of specialized equipment in anticipation of a boss battle or an enemy type that will be hard to deal with otherwise. These gameplay designs would make for excellent teaching tools--if this my first time playing a game with an involved job system. It's not. These sections also hurts the game's replay value, since even experienced players don't always have total freedom to experiment with the different job classes and set up the party they want to use. In fact, the job system in this game is kind of a letdown. One problem with being able to change characters' jobs at will is keeping track of all their equipment. While there is a fair amount of overlap in terms of which jobs can use what weapons and armors, carrying around or storing all that junk gets annoying after a while. And while most jobs progress pretty quickly, there isn't too much incentive to gain job levels with most classes. At most, a higher job level changes one or two minor calculations for class-specific actions you won't always use all that often. Job level is more important for mages, since I'm pretty sure it influences the MP they gain. Unlike the job system in, say, FFV, there are no major rewards for mastering a class either. You can't take abilities or even base stats (except HP) with you when you change classes. But I think my biggest gripe about this game is its horrendously uneven gameplay. This game expects you to grind for several levels between just about every major dungeon. Try to go straight from one plot point to the next and you will probably lose. The boss battles are the worst offenders of all--they are all really, really hard. Regardless of how easily you managed to get through a dungeon's standard enemies, when you reach the boss, there is a good chance you will get a game over. And with no mid-dungeon save points, that means replaying an entire chunk of the game. Each boss is exactly the same too--they all attack twice with either hard physical attacks (that can inflict statuses) or magic spells that hit your entire party for heavy damage. The challenge doesn't come from figuring out an optimal strategy; it comes entirely from luck, as bosses have an unusual tendency to target your weakest characters and throw you back on your heels in survival mode. The game gets better as it goes along, fortunately, and the vast job system does provide a lot of replay value. I'm just pretty sure I would rather replay Final Fantasy I on the GBA than fight through this game again--what with all its problems and its decided lack of polish.

												Final Fantasy 3 has joined Final Fantasy 7 and 8 on Steam, now keep in mind this is Final Fantasy 3 and not Final Fantasy 6 which was released in the US as 3(seems some people are still confused about that). This is also a port of the iOS/Android version which in turn was a port of the DS remake which took the orginal Famicom game and gave it a upgrade with a FMV intro, 3d graphics, though ps1/N64 level 3d graphics so expect some low poly models, revamped soundtrack and a reworked storyline which is still very light in narrative and a few other changes such as not starting the game with your full party and not having access to your first set of jobs till after the second dungeon. In the original you get your first set of jobs after beating the first boss in the intro/tutorial dungeon which makes the game a bit more harder when you reach the second dungeon. Now this game is fairly old school so expect to have to do quite a bit of grinding for exp. before tackling the next dungeon or else your going to have a bad time, seriously the next dungeon after the tutorial one is packed with hard hitting undead that will wipe the floor with your party. The game was the first in the series to make use of the "Job" system which means you pick what "job" each of your four charecters have and can change them for diffrent ones but unlike Final Fantasy 5 you really can't keep the skills learned from each job, so in other words you can have a charecter be a white mage and then become a ninja and still have access to white mage magic but you can move magic between charecters. But despite this, the light narrative, the grinding and the old school "ask around to get clues on to what you may need to do next" style of gameplay it's pretty fun if not hard. So if you can look past the low poly models and the old school RPG mechanics this is a worth while game but not for the asking price, maybe 9.99 or so sure but not at 14.99 so you may want to wait to see if it goes on sale and grab it then.

												There's a reason this is the forgotten FF, and it's not just because lack of a translation for decades.For those uninitiated to FF and JRPGs in general: Look elsewhere for your introduction, should you want one.For those more inclined, I point you to FFV first.For those who have played FFV, this is the same but less:  Little carries between jobs and switching is a nuisance, Boss AI is very limited (You pray they don't focus attacks on your healer and they can replace one of their attacks per turn with a spell, that's every boss for the entire game), there's no save points in dungeons, the plot is insultingly basic without even being enjoyably stupid, some jobs are direct upgrades others for no good reason, speed is very random in battles meaning healing is dangerously unreliable, the last dungeon is actually four dungeons and everything's so unmemorable that it's generally difficult to remember where you're going or why.There are some good points, some cool uses of Mini and Toad, the job costumes are good and there's a large variety of jobs, there's some depth (speed is random, but thief is fast enough that it probably doesn't matter), the story is lighthearted, the visuals are pretty good in the reboot and the music is catchy.  There's also a guy unironically named Goldor who lives in a golden house filled with golden monsters and fights you by beating you with the gold gauntlets on his gold armour, so that's worth something.Still, unless you've got to finish every FF, you can't get much more vanilla than this one.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Final Fantasy III was initially a mystery to gamers outside of Japan, having only been released on the Famicom in 1990. Since then, Final Fantasy III has been re-released several times; Nintendo DS, Playstation Portable, Wii’s Virtual Console, iOS, Android, and most recently making its way here to Steam. The game’s format and mechanics may feel a bit dated/unusual to those familiar with newer Final Fantasy titles, but I believe that the game still provides a worthwhile playing experience.My first exposure to this game was the Nintendo DS version, which I picked up used for quite a bargain. That version is a 3D remake of the original Famicom game, and it appears that this PC version stayed loyal to that style. Due to the limited specifications on the Nintendo DS, I always felt that the game was a bit held back in the graphics and sound department. This PC version seems to have given the artwork better treatment, and appears to resemble the PSP version of the game more closely. I was concerned that the graphics would be overly pixelated due to the small resolution on handhelds, but was pleasantly surprised to see that the graphics felt right for PC.The music, as usual in Final Fantasy titles, is superb. As a remake, they stayed very true to the themes present on the Famicom release. Many of the musical themes fit the mood of the game quite well, allowing the player to enjoy a calm stroll through a town or a hectic boss battle at the end of a dungeon. The sound quality is superb, as well, and doesn’t have the muffled sounds that the DS version provided.Final Fantasy III’s combat system strays far from the system of its predecessor, and attempts to advance the system that was originally present in the original Final Fantasy. The player has the option to choose from a variety of jobs. As the player advances through the game and completes various quest “checkpoints” (for lack of a better word), additional jobs open up. Some of these jobs which offer a brand new range of healing, magic and utility, while some are simply upgrades to existing jobs. There are over two dozen jobs in total, giving players many chances to experiment. Along with jobs, this is the first Final Fantasy game to introduce summons. So if you’re familiar with summons in later titles such as Shiva and Bahamut, you’ll be right at home.An immersing story has been an important part of the Final Fantasy franchise in recent years. Going back in time, however, it wasn’t always this way. In Final Fantasy III, the story is notably flat compared to the extended stories present in modern RPG titles. It’s easy to understand, rarely sees plot twists, and has a relatively small cast of characters. It’s nothing spectacular, but it was a step ahead from the two previous entries in the series. Unlike the Famicom Final Fantasy III, however, the characters in this version are given formal names. Despite the limited storytelling, I still feel it’s pleasant; just don't go in expecting a 50 hour long legendary tale.The difficulty of this game is a bit jarring. The early game starts off quite bearable, giving players the ability to simply auto attack their way through many of the fiends. As the game progresses, the difficulty spikes up considerably. The final dungeons are notoriously difficult due to lack of save points and insufficient materials provided throughout the game. Compared to the difficulty of some modern Final Fantasy titles, the harsh difficulty in this game might turn some people away. But if you can fight through the barrage of random encounters and somehow make it through the dungeon, you’ll be rewarded with quite a sense of accomplishment.In conclusion, I feel that Final Fantasy III is a worthy purchase for those who wish to revisit the roots of the Final Fantasy franchise, and JRPGs in general. It’s difficult, but rewarding. A worthy game for the name “Final Fantasy.”

												I started playing final fantasy games about 10 years ago. I started with final fantasy X and was hooked shortly after. The series is amazing but I never went back to play anything below FFX. I heard the hype behind FFVII but I never like to buy into hype because it only serves to disappoint me usually. That being said, the very early final fantasys had sprites and I was not too interested in the low detail so I stayed on the other side of FFX.Now, I saw this on sale at the Humble Store and I figured it would be a good time to try the older Final Fantasy games, given the polish this game had recieved.It has a piece of gaming that I had missed with all the new games in the world now. It makes you want to play just because you want to discover new things. Not for the sake of driving the plot forward or saving X amount of people. It lets you do what you want and I get legitimately excited when I open a chest or find a new hidden area. It makes me feel like when I first started to play video games all so long ago and I haven't had this feeling since Valkyrie Profile:Leneth for the PSP. I actually want to grind and level my party up so I can kill monster and gain treasure. Almost a feeling akin to Skyrim but less open.I guess it plays to the basic nature that players want to get treasure and go adventuring. Posted: February 23
												I've been trying to work my way through this game, but it's been a slow road. I played it a few hours, got bored, tried FFV to see a better version of the Job System (and pretty much everything else), then came back to this game. I played a few more hours, got bored, then played FFIV because I wanted to play an FF game but was having a tough time playing this game. Then I played FFIV: The After Years, couldn't make it in very far at all because it's a tacky quasi-asset-flip of FFIV with a different story that rips off parts of FFIV's plot, and came back here to FFIII again...or at least I came back to my Steam games list and winced, just staring at this game on the list, not wanting to play it because I had so little motivation and enjoyment from playing it.Anyway, I've made up my mind that I think I'm just going to stop playing FFIII. I played plenty of it to know that I don't like it and that forcing myself to play more of it won't make me like it, so I'll go into a few things I did and didn't like, and explain quite why it is that I have no interest in proceeding more into the game.Final Fantasy Music is Nearly Incapable of SuckingI didn't like FFIII, but I have to give credit where it's due. This game's soundtrack is great. I highly recommend listening to it on Youtube while you're reading articles online or a book, etc. I've gone back and listened to the soundtracks from I & II, and this series just has great music. Nobuo Uematsu is the man. You owe it to yourself to listen to the soundtracks of all the FF games he worked on, and some of more recent ones that even he didn't write. I do not support his "Crazy Chocobo" song, though, from FFXIII-2.GraphicsI don't have much to say here. It's got a sort of cutesy look that works well enough. The enemies look a bit meh, even compared to FFIV, which is done in the same style. This version of FFIII definitely looks better, graphically, than screenshots I've seen of the NES version, obviously. My only qualm about the graphics is the need to manually zoom in, which gives you a stupidly close view of everything, and you have to do it fairly often to look fo secrets. The graphics are pretty good.Job System WoesThis is a bit of a precursor to my gameplay section of the review. The job system lets you switch your characters from being warriors, to black mages or red mages, etc. You can do it any time, based on which crystal(s) you've reached in the game. I have issues with FFV, but its job system has reasons to use other jobs. In FFIII, on the other hand, if you are playing the game intelligently, you will almost never change jobs. When you get a better job, you drop the old one and never touch it again. You're rewarded for picking one class/job and sticking with it very far into the game. There are no benefits carried over between jobs/classes based on your progress in a different job/class, and it's just so pointless.FFI and FFII allowed players to select the permanent jobs of their party members when starting the game. Since FFIII has an ideal set of jobs, based on the aforementioned info I covered, FFI and FFI handled jobs better by cutting out the silliness of switching jobs when switching jobs is almost useless. The only times it is worthwhile in FFIII is if you make the entire party something like blackbelts, which will make you able to wipe pretty much every enemy encounter in a turn or two, amounting to easy mode, and switching to your diverse party for the occasional boss, only. Oh, and it's supposedly worthwhile if you plan on power-gaming to character level 99 to use the onion knight class and steamroll the game. What's really silly is that the most efficient way to level your characters' jobs is to have everyone block for a few rounds against the easiest enemy in the entire game, then win the battle. You can reliably level up a job one time per battle, and it takes very little time to do this, thus discouraging fighting as you travel, or even fighting in new areas with tougher monsters. Instead, it enourages you to stay in the easiest map in the game, grinding a job to max, then wiping the floor with everything that's not a boss.As a power-gamer myself, I can tell you that this is pretty broken, but I didn't find this aspect fun, even.Long story short, this job system is pointless and they may as well have just done the FFI and FFII "pick your party member classes/jobs" permanently at the start of the game, and just stick to character levels, because my characters had the same basic function for my entire playtime.Story etc (or the lack thereof)If you ever played an FF game from the SNES era, or anything newer than that, and you thought "that story was a bit too simple," FFIII is going to amaze you at how much more simple and boring it can be. I did not complete the game, but from my journeys to the crystals I visited, I was never once interested or entertained by a single moment in the story, or by a single character. I'm not asking for much. I found FFIV's story to be meh, and its characters to be mostly quite shallow, but FFIII managed to suck every ounce of intrigue out of its setting. As far in as I got, the game was bankrupt of anything interesting going on, or any characters I actually liked.In summary, it's one of those stupid "You're the heroes of light!" plots where you go see a crystal, visit a town, go to a dungeon, kill a boss, repeat ad nauseum. That happens in other FF games, but they tend to have more interesting stuff happening to keep players intrigued. Here, however, the phrase "I couldn't care less" would somehow manage to be an understatement.Okay Gameplay This isn't bad, but it's also not all that good. I do enjoy how the game is turn-based, like FFX is later in the series. I like the active time combat system some of the other games have, but turn-based is nice for coming up with interesting combat strategies that the ATD system might cause players to overlook due to the time constraints of said system. The combat works nice enough, but the game lacks some of the spell variety of FFIV, and without the game mixing up your party like FFIV does, or having a job system with a reason to switch often, like FFV does, meaning FFIII is markedly simple. Simple can be good, but when everything else in the game was so lame to me, I really needed the gameplay to draw me in, and it did not succeed on that front.ConclusionWith FFIII, you get quality music, okay graphics and gameplay, and a world that's Final Fantasy at its most regurgitated basic fantasy level, which characters who are arguably more disinteresting than the setting and what I saw of the story. I am not disparaging FFIV or FFV, because I think they did a pretty good job with the pre-FFVI fantasy settings the series leaned toward. The job system is one of FFIII's biggest features, but it's flawed to the point that its existence was not needed and choosing classes at the start would have been just fine, as in FFI and FFII. My recommendation is that you avoid this game, play something better instead, and check out the FF soundtracks, because there are some great songs out there.

												So, first ever Steam review so please be nice!As a long time FF fan, I picked FF3 up as a historical curiosity more than anything, and frankly, that's the only reason to play it. The world is twee and standard, filled with cut-and-paste towns devoid of charm or character.Overall, if you're simply looking for a simple fun romp through JRPG tropes you could do a lot worse, but don't expect any more than that.  For more mature, deep or involving games, you should probably look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Ah, FFIII. Originally released on the Famicom only in Japan, which caused quite a lot of confusion with the numbering, this is the last Final Fantasy (or at least the last numbered one) made for the third generation of gaming (NES/Sega Master System). After a 3D remake on the DS and a few ports later, it's finally on Steam.Unfortunately, this remake is *too* faithful, and it doesn't quite hold up. There's no real sense of direction after the first dungeon, which you are dropped in straight away (literally). *SPOILERS* After you deal with a few random encounters and beat the boss, a crystal talks to you, and you appear on the overworld. You go to your town, watch a friend get bullied and then run off, talk to the village elders who basically say, "You have been chosen since birth by the crystals! It was no coincidence that it spoke to you now! Oh, and by the way, you're adopted!" (I kid you not, they flat out tell your character that he's adopted, and he has no reaction to that. It's not even because he's a silent protag, he just doesn't say anything back)*SPOILERS END*Unlike the FFIV DS remake, there are no thought bubbles that appear when you use your menu on the world map, which would add some character to the otherwise stereotypical characters. You have your flat, adventurous main character, his best friend, a random girl you meet on an airship, and a castle guard. By the way, they're all 14 for whatever reason, even the castle guard, and they all look like they could be older. Don't expect the rest of the game to be any less cliche.The OST is nice, I suppose. The standard town and battle music is good, but not great. The music for the Sealed Cave, the first dungeon, is...interesting. It's good, but it's not really what I would've expected for the first non-tutorial dungeon. I especially like "Into the Crystal Cave", as well as "Eternal Wind", and "Jinn's Curse", and that's all that I've liked from what I've heard so far.The plot is slightly more complex than Final Fantasy I in that your characters actually speak and have...well...character! The plot is still plastic, and you still have to go on a cliche fetch quest for crystals after being declared the chosen ones, though. Also, *MINOR SPOILERS* you get an airship not even an hour into the game, which seems odd to me. I thought airships were things you got in the middle of the game, not right at the beginning with no effort. I'm not sure if I'm upset about it, because on one hand you get to experience the freedom of flight earlier, and on the other hand it cheapens the concept of getting an airship.*MINOR SPOILERS OVER*The visuals are probably the best part about this game. The chibi style and colorful palette makes the world seem inviting and playful, which is probably the only reason I even played more after I got out of the tutorial dungeon. In this case, the graphics did make the game for me.The gameplay, like the plot, is only slightly more complex than Final Fantasy I's. If you've played FFI, you know that if you make all your characters attack one enemy and the first hit or so kills it, the rest of your attacks will be "ineffective", because their target is already dead. This is the first game to fix that, and it does so by automatically selecting a new target for a given character's attack. Brilliant, right? Still, because this is FFIII and not FFIV, there is no ATB, which means that instead of a gauge filling up for a given character so they can attack, you just select new commands at the end of each "turn", like Pokemon. However, Pokemon has several type advantages and disadvantages, 4 moves per Pokemon, and loads of other things to make the combat more complex, while FFIII just has your choice of weapons, and I suppose a unique ability here and there when you meet more playable characters. Sure, the elemental black magic will be more effective against certain types, but it's still not the same complexity as in Pokemon, and even then, not everyone has black magic (although there is a way to give everyone black magic, but it's not worth it). For an apt analogy concerning FFIII's combat compared to FFIV's, think of coaching a football/soccer/other sport game vs. playing in one. FFIII is where you coach.Oh, still on the topic of combat, sometimes enemies are faster than you, sometimes you're faster than them. It doesn't even seen to be a constant thing during the same battle, and so it can't possibly be due to different enemies being different levels even though they're the same type of enemy. This pretty much makes any strategy impossible to rely on 100%, which means straight up luck is now a factor. I suppose luck is also a factor in real life combat, but this isn't real life. When you get to the first actual dungeon, prepare to get destroyed if you didn't grind a lot beforehand. Yeah, it's one of those RPGs.Should FFIII have stayed in Japan? Nah. While I bash on it quite a bit in this review, it's great to look at how far the franchise has come. Gotta have bad games to appreciate good ones, and all. Still, I can't in good faith recommend this to anyone, or at least this version, RPG lover or not. I hear the PSP version is the best, but I have not played much of it despite owning it. I'll update this review if/when I bring myself to play more of this version, but for now, I must give it the thumbs down.

												Short review. This is a plotless, characterless, timewasting grind.Long Review.Lets start with the basics. I used to play the old final fantasy games on the SNES, which were great and even now worth playing on an emulator. I saw this on sale, saw the job class system and was reminded of one of my favourite FF games with the same idea. I thought i'd enjoy this game even more with the enhanced graphics and suchlike. Wrong.The job classesI'm about a quarter of the way through the game and i'm about level 25 out of level 99 on my first job for each character. It is only because of reading the wiki page I find out that there is no significant benefit at all to mastering a class.In the prior version, sticking with a class and mastering it was a good idea. If one of your characters mastered being a white mage, then you could select white magic as a secondary ability when you started a new class. This allowed for interesting and varied job combinations. This new version makes you start from scratch every time you start a new job. There are even better versions of the starting jobs which you will have to grind through again to make them any good since they will draw no benefit from having ground from the basic class. Utter time wasting and demoralising.The charactersWeak and shallow. A few lines of dialogue to establish the basic idea and then thats it. You might get one line here and there to create the illusion that the characters have any depth, but really? I've not met one person in the game which with a worthwhile personality. Even the villains which should be the driving force of a game are non-exisitant. Once you've ground through a dungeon you get to meet someone with two lines of dialogue before you kill them. Yawn. This is just endless grinding, over and over.The plotWait? There's a plot? Really? A few lines from some crystal to tell you that you're the chosen one and then you're off. Um... is that it? You bet it is. Save the world? Uh... it looks fine to me. No maurading armies, no cataclysmic natural disasters, no iconic villians with master plans. Just a vague reference to darkness being imbalanced. It's like a stoned aromatherapist ate some alphabet soup and♥♥♥♥♥♥out a story.OverallIf you like endless grinding and having to start characters over again and again, not having to worry about plots, characters or indeed anything being memorable about the game, then this is the one for you.I'm going to be uninstalling this and finding a SNES emulator to play some decent final fantasy.

												Final Fantasy III is an unrewarding grind with a so-simple-it's-convoluted story reminiscent of Kingdom Hearts'.  The story is about the balance between light and darkness--and the game lectures and reminds the player about this balance a few hundred times throughout, as New Age-plagued JRPGs often do.Its gameplay is where it fails on virtually every level: Most of the jobs are useless, half the abilities in the game are bugged and simply don't work, and players will lose hours upon hours of progress due to a complete absence of in-dungeon save points.  You can only save on the world map, and some dungeons are 5+ hours long.Even players who only desire a peek at the advent of Final Fantasy's Job System will be disappointed, as the game's combat shoehorns players into a select few jobs, rendering the remainder not only unusable, but boring and uninspired as well.  For example, over half of the game's jobs are mere upgrades to existing jobs, offering nothing of substance on a gameplay level.The music and graphics are sometimes surprisingly good.I recommend this game to hardcore completionists and to Final Fantasy XIV fans who want to see the origins of the "Crystal Tower" raid.  To anyone else: don't waste your time.  Final Fantasy III is just not good enough to justify the time investment.

Quick review: +Fun battle system+Fun development system+Interesting world+Good writing-Story feels its age-Development system lacks any major depth-Convoluted magic system-Difficulty curve is weird*This review is based on the game Final Fantasy III, not just this particular port*Final Fantasy III is a mixed bag that shows it age but still remains solid in gameplay, development and fun.The story is standard fare, you play as an orphan collecting crystals and saving the world. Obviously there are more nuances there, but this is where the game truly feels its age with each character essentially being a blank canvas. The writing is interesting enough to offset the generic overtones though, it's generally something that Square are very good at. I want to emphasize that the story itself isn't bad though, you just shouldn't go in expecting something incredible.(There's nothing wrong with this trope, seeing as Square was a large part of its popularity)The gameplay is traditional turn based, using your agility stat to determine where you appear in a queue. Some abilities have higher priorities and will therefore be used first, if your agility equals someone elses.The development system uses the Job system, and FFIII was the first Final Fantasy that let you freely change jobs outside of battle. You have jobs like White Mage (healer), Black Mage (nuker) and Knight (tank). There are lots of jobs to use, and you can make a party of your choosing. The development system is relatively shallow, but has enough depth to keep things interesting. This system was then perfected in Final Fantasy V. (steam release please)The Magic system is a little bit iffy, instead of having a standard MP pool, you have a number of uses tacked on to each level of magic (which raises through levels) which means you could use nine level 1 spells and still use a level 2 spell after that, assuming you had charges for level 2 magic. You're also limited to only 3 slots per level of magic, meaning you have to make a decision on which magicks you want to use (especially if you use a red mage) I feel like they improved on this in subsequent titles. (MP pool, no choosing magicks)The difficulty curve can make the game frustrating at points and too easy at other points, but it's never unfair or completely simple.Visually the game looks OK. I've never personally been a fan of the DS esque chibi art though, so take that with a grain of salt. The game itself upscales pretty well, and looks nice on the PC unless you stare too intently and some of the textures.The controls are ok, and very intuitive if you're using a controller and you've ever played another Final Fantasy game. The menus can be a bit sluggish sometimes, but it's never to the point of frustration. The zoom feature can be a pain sometimes too, but again it's never too bad.Is this game worth the price tag? Yes and no. You will get £11($17)'s worth of content out of the game, but it does seem a little pricey seeing as this is a port of a port, and considering that you can buy FFVII and VIII for so cheap on steam currently. If you're a fan of the series or want a solid turn based RPG to keep you busy for a while, then I'd suggest picking it up. If you're unsure then I would wait until it comes on sale.Oh and the music? The music is fantastic.

												Before getting down to brass tacks, one needs to be reminded that this is an old game.  A 23+ year old game, actually.  So with that in mind, there can be times when FF3 feels archaic, grindy, and vague.  This is an NES game with a new coat of paint.  So, do not expect hand holding or a cake walk.  With that out of the way...This is actually a port of a port, which usually instills fear into my heart, and while others have reported bugs, glitches, and downright unplayable circumstances, I have been lucky.  Nothing technical has disturbed my playthrough.  However, that doesn't mean the game is free from these issues.  It's kind of a, "buy at your own risk" sort of deal...As for the game itself.  The new paint, while cartoonish, resonates very well with me.  While in battle, I get this odd deja vu feeling, because the art design and animations resemble FF9's quite a bit.  The world is just gorgeous compared to the NES version.  The music is the original, but redone with modern technology...you know...so it matches the non 8 bit paint job.The writing, however, is atrocious.  I haven't played the original with the english fansubs, so I cannot compare the two, but this is easily B-team writing, if not C-team.  But, that's ok, because this game doesn't have a particularly good story anyway.  The story is...well...an NES story (it is basic and generic.  We don't see one of those classic Final Fantasy stories till the release of the SNES and FF4.)  If you want a good story, YOU WON"T FIND IT HERE!But what you will find here is a fun and addictive leveling system.  Oh yes, the jobs system.  See, unlike some of the later games in the series where there are more party members than we know what to do with, this game has only our 4 innocent teens.  So, instead of leveling/grinding multiple people who may represent different classes, you focus on the same four heroes but have the option of switching their class/job.  There are 23 different jobs and every character can level each of those jobs (independantly of the other characters) to level 99.  This allows for diverse parties and the ability to adapt one's party for specific situations.  It's not as awesome as the ICONIC FF5 job system, but, this came out before that...on a weaker system...with a lower production budget...and a smaller dev team...But, being simpler doesn't mean it's any less fun.As for the battles themselves.  The ATB system hasn't been invented yet.  It's oldschool turn based.  The player inputs commands for all 4 characters at the same time, and they are executed in an order detrmined by the stats of both the characters and the enemies.  Then, repeat.  This can be a good or bad thing.  It can be frustrating if your mage strattles that line of sometimes healing before the enemy attacks and sometimes after it attacks...despite being the exact same enemy.  The system can be controlled to a degree if one knows the speed of their characters...and equips gear to make the characters faster or slower.So, if one wants a TL;DR version...-It's an OLD game (1990) with a new coat of paintPros:-Seems remarkably stable despite being a port of a port.-Job system is addictive and fun.-Plenty of side quests/optional dungeons for treasure hunting.-CHALLENGING!  Unlike many new games released today where one can get through without dying, there were many sections which took me a few tries to get through.  Strategy through trial and error creates a sense of accomplishment.Cons:-Horrible writing for a non existant story (indicative of late 80's/early 90's technology and gaming scene.)-Kind of expensive for being a port...If you are looking for a nostalgic, old-school JRPG game, here you go.  It's gritty.  It certainly won't appeal to many, "youngins," but if looked through the lens of the time it was released, it is a solid, and recommended experience.  8.2/10

												A classic RPG. Chances are that if you enjoy any RPG's at all, you'll most likely find something you like in this. This is a port of the iOS version of Final Fantasy III, so it has an upscaled 720p version of the graphics. With that being said, things still look quite primitive and blocky, and the battle arenas more often than not look like you're stood inside a disc floating in space with a jpg wrapped around it. If that kind of thing is absolutely unbearable to you, than maybe avoid this title. If you dont care too much about graphics, and you're all about the gameplay, FFIII works on a classic turn-based system, and has a classic Job system that Final Fantasy is renowned for. Character classes and archetypes are classic, recognisable and feel unique enough to make a difference in how you fight. If you've played Bravely Default, Final Fantasy 5, Final Fantasy 10-2 or even some of the Dragon Quest games, you'll feel right at home here with this classic rendition of the Job system.FF3 provides you with quite a challenge at times, especially with the bosses, and even some monsters (Lookin' at you chimera mage) Can surprise you with an attack that can wipe out your party if you're rushing too much. I'm not saying be prepared to grind for years, but if you try to charge through, you're probably going to get frustrated when you reach the next crystal boss. Some of the achievements are a serious pain, such as the 100% Beastiary and 100% Treasure achievement, due to some areas where certain monsters are missable completely, and the same is true for chests with no possibility to return to those areas. The last achievement that can be annoying is the "Jack of All Trades" achievement which requires you to reach Job Level 99 for every job, with every character. This is literally a matter of grinding, and even using optimal methods, it will take you several hours of mindless boredom and repetition to accomplish.Overall, aside from some of the grinding, and the graphics leaving something to be desired, I'm proud to have this title in my library, and you should be too! Fingers crossed that Square finds it within themselves to bring more and more FF titles, and other RPG's to Steam.

Now keep in mind that this is the real Final Fantasy III (not the Super Nintendo Final Fantasy III which was actually Final Fantasy VI, but renamed FFIII since it was the third FF game to hit the US). Which determine your skill sets and which weapons/armor you can equip, but don't worry you can change your job at anytime. You also level up your jobs just like you level up your character. So the higher the job level the better you'll be at that job, and you don't lose any job levels by switching back and forth. The story is nothing special, but being from 1990 it's pretty good. Bottom line is if you like the old Final Fantasy titles (you'll need to do some grinding), and you don't mind the graphics then you'll enjoy the game.

												A classic RPG. Chances are that if you enjoy any RPG's at all, you'll most likely find something you like in this. This is a port of the iOS version of Final Fantasy III, so it has an upscaled 720p version of the graphics. With that being said, things still look quite primitive and blocky, and the battle arenas more often than not look like you're stood inside a disc floating in space with a jpg wrapped around it. If that kind of thing is absolutely unbearable to you, than maybe avoid this title. If you dont care too much about graphics, and you're all about the gameplay, FFIII works on a classic turn-based system, and has a classic Job system that Final Fantasy is renowned for. Character classes and archetypes are classic, recognisable and feel unique enough to make a difference in how you fight. If you've played Bravely Default, Final Fantasy 5, Final Fantasy 10-2 or even some of the Dragon Quest games, you'll feel right at home here with this classic rendition of the Job system.FF3 provides you with quite a challenge at times, especially with the bosses, and even some monsters (Lookin' at you chimera mage) Can surprise you with an attack that can wipe out your party if you're rushing too much. I'm not saying be prepared to grind for years, but if you try to charge through, you're probably going to get frustrated when you reach the next crystal boss. Some of the achievements are a serious pain, such as the 100% Beastiary and 100% Treasure achievement, due to some areas where certain monsters are missable completely, and the same is true for chests with no possibility to return to those areas. The last achievement that can be annoying is the "Jack of All Trades" achievement which requires you to reach Job Level 99 for every job, with every character. This is literally a matter of grinding, and even using optimal methods, it will take you several hours of mindless boredom and repetition to accomplish.Overall, aside from some of the grinding, and the graphics leaving something to be desired, I'm proud to have this title in my library, and you should be too! Fingers crossed that Square finds it within themselves to bring more and more FF titles, and other RPG's to Steam.

												Before getting down to brass tacks, one needs to be reminded that this is an old game.  A 23+ year old game, actually.  So with that in mind, there can be times when FF3 feels archaic, grindy, and vague.  This is an NES game with a new coat of paint.  So, do not expect hand holding or a cake walk.  With that out of the way...This is actually a port of a port, which usually instills fear into my heart, and while others have reported bugs, glitches, and downright unplayable circumstances, I have been lucky.  Nothing technical has disturbed my playthrough.  However, that doesn't mean the game is free from these issues.  It's kind of a, "buy at your own risk" sort of deal...As for the game itself.  The new paint, while cartoonish, resonates very well with me.  While in battle, I get this odd deja vu feeling, because the art design and animations resemble FF9's quite a bit.  The world is just gorgeous compared to the NES version.  The music is the original, but redone with modern technology...you know...so it matches the non 8 bit paint job.The writing, however, is atrocious.  I haven't played the original with the english fansubs, so I cannot compare the two, but this is easily B-team writing, if not C-team.  But, that's ok, because this game doesn't have a particularly good story anyway.  The story is...well...an NES story (it is basic and generic.  We don't see one of those classic Final Fantasy stories till the release of the SNES and FF4.)  If you want a good story, YOU WON"T FIND IT HERE!But what you will find here is a fun and addictive leveling system.  Oh yes, the jobs system.  See, unlike some of the later games in the series where there are more party members than we know what to do with, this game has only our 4 innocent teens.  So, instead of leveling/grinding multiple people who may represent different classes, you focus on the same four heroes but have the option of switching their class/job.  There are 23 different jobs and every character can level each of those jobs (independantly of the other characters) to level 99.  This allows for diverse parties and the ability to adapt one's party for specific situations.  It's not as awesome as the ICONIC FF5 job system, but, this came out before that...on a weaker system...with a lower production budget...and a smaller dev team...But, being simpler doesn't mean it's any less fun.As for the battles themselves.  The ATB system hasn't been invented yet.  It's oldschool turn based.  The player inputs commands for all 4 characters at the same time, and they are executed in an order detrmined by the stats of both the characters and the enemies.  Then, repeat.  This can be a good or bad thing.  It can be frustrating if your mage strattles that line of sometimes healing before the enemy attacks and sometimes after it attacks...despite being the exact same enemy.  The system can be controlled to a degree if one knows the speed of their characters...and equips gear to make the characters faster or slower.So, if one wants a TL;DR version...-It's an OLD game (1990) with a new coat of paintPros:-Seems remarkably stable despite being a port of a port.-Job system is addictive and fun.-Plenty of side quests/optional dungeons for treasure hunting.-CHALLENGING!  Unlike many new games released today where one can get through without dying, there were many sections which took me a few tries to get through.  Strategy through trial and error creates a sense of accomplishment.Cons:-Horrible writing for a non existant story (indicative of late 80's/early 90's technology and gaming scene.)-Kind of expensive for being a port...If you are looking for a nostalgic, old-school JRPG game, here you go.  It's gritty.  It certainly won't appeal to many, "youngins," but if looked through the lens of the time it was released, it is a solid, and recommended experience.  8.2/10

												Before getting down to brass tacks, one needs to be reminded that this is an old game.  A 23+ year old game, actually.  So with that in mind, there can be times when FF3 feels archaic, grindy, and vague.  This is an NES game with a new coat of paint.  So, do not expect hand holding or a cake walk.  With that out of the way...This is actually a port of a port, which usually instills fear into my heart, and while others have reported bugs, glitches, and downright unplayable circumstances, I have been lucky.  Nothing technical has disturbed my playthrough.  However, that doesn't mean the game is free from these issues.  It's kind of a, "buy at your own risk" sort of deal...As for the game itself.  The new paint, while cartoonish, resonates very well with me.  While in battle, I get this odd deja vu feeling, because the art design and animations resemble FF9's quite a bit.  The world is just gorgeous compared to the NES version.  The music is the original, but redone with modern technology...you know...so it matches the non 8 bit paint job.The writing, however, is atrocious.  I haven't played the original with the english fansubs, so I cannot compare the two, but this is easily B-team writing, if not C-team.  But, that's ok, because this game doesn't have a particularly good story anyway.  The story is...well...an NES story (it is basic and generic.  We don't see one of those classic Final Fantasy stories till the release of the SNES and FF4.)  If you want a good story, YOU WON"T FIND IT HERE!But what you will find here is a fun and addictive leveling system.  Oh yes, the jobs system.  See, unlike some of the later games in the series where there are more party members than we know what to do with, this game has only our 4 innocent teens.  So, instead of leveling/grinding multiple people who may represent different classes, you focus on the same four heroes but have the option of switching their class/job.  There are 23 different jobs and every character can level each of those jobs (independantly of the other characters) to level 99.  This allows for diverse parties and the ability to adapt one's party for specific situations.  It's not as awesome as the ICONIC FF5 job system, but, this came out before that...on a weaker system...with a lower production budget...and a smaller dev team...But, being simpler doesn't mean it's any less fun.As for the battles themselves.  The ATB system hasn't been invented yet.  It's oldschool turn based.  The player inputs commands for all 4 characters at the same time, and they are executed in an order detrmined by the stats of both the characters and the enemies.  Then, repeat.  This can be a good or bad thing.  It can be frustrating if your mage strattles that line of sometimes healing before the enemy attacks and sometimes after it attacks...despite being the exact same enemy.  The system can be controlled to a degree if one knows the speed of their characters...and equips gear to make the characters faster or slower.So, if one wants a TL;DR version...-It's an OLD game (1990) with a new coat of paintPros:-Seems remarkably stable despite being a port of a port.-Job system is addictive and fun.-Plenty of side quests/optional dungeons for treasure hunting.-CHALLENGING!  Unlike many new games released today where one can get through without dying, there were many sections which took me a few tries to get through.  Strategy through trial and error creates a sense of accomplishment.Cons:-Horrible writing for a non existant story (indicative of late 80's/early 90's technology and gaming scene.)-Kind of expensive for being a port...If you are looking for a nostalgic, old-school JRPG game, here you go.  It's gritty.  It certainly won't appeal to many, "youngins," but if looked through the lens of the time it was released, it is a solid, and recommended experience.  8.2/10

Great class system, typical FF Crystal story, hidden items and chest, a bit of grind. Great for those looking for a classic JRPGStoryLike in the original Final Fantasy III you play as the four Onion Knights: Luneth, Arc, Refia and Butts. These guys were basically created to give the onion knights a sense of individual character and design. Anyway you start the story off with amnesia in typical JRPG fashion, you fight some monsters in a cave and then get told you're the chosen one. You gather your four party members within the first two-three hours and then you're off saving the flying continent from Xande using the power of the four crystals. The story is incredibly weak, but that's not why you're here.   Battle Mechanics and GameplayDon't go into this expecting anything complex, it's a classic JRPG It uses a turn based system setup like so:AttackClass Abilities/MagicGuardItems Flee (If available)Grinding isn't too necessary if you're not fleeing every encounter and if you have set strategies for the bosses, but this is only if you'e hunting hidden chests for hidden equipment. However grinding is incredibly viable if you're looking to 100% the game. Turns are purely based on characters attack speeds, there is no ATB in this game. SoundSoundtrack really isn't too memorable aside from the battle themes, chocobo theme and the dancer themes. Not much Choice and FreedomsThis game boasts a unique 23 classes all with their own different playstyles, to go along with the boatload of classes to choose from you also have a heavy amount of character customization, classes are not limited to just one weapon type, you have access to over a hundred weapons and armor throughout the game. This game really treats you with the variety of equipment and class builds.  Exploration in dungeons and the overworld will benefit you as you'll find alot of hidden loot, but the story progression is incredibly linear.
